metadata.title: Databases: Fundamentals of SQL. An easy to understand explanation with… | by competitor-cutter | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: This post by no means can completely cover every aspect of SQL functionality, however, I’m attempting to create a quick reference guide that provides the practical aspect of SQL and shows important…

all_paragraphs: This post by no means can completely cover every aspect of SQL functionality, however, I’m attempting to create a quick reference guide that provides the practical aspect of SQL and shows important functionality in a concise way. If you find any mistakes please do not hesitate to comment it out.
When we write SQL statement they should be in same order as they are written above. We can also see the code below:
SELECT * FROM <condition>WHERE <condition>GROUP BY <condition> HAVING <condition>ORDER BY <condition>
In terms of execution however, the flow is different. That means when the SQL statements run on server side it is read in same order as written below:

FROM (it select the table that is required)WHERE (it filters the rows based on condition)GROUP BY (it aggregates the result that was filtered)HAVING (additional level of filtering for aggregated values)SELECT (select the appropriate columns from the result)ORDER BY (arrange values in ascending or descending)

The result shows we have 481 instances of orders that had quantity 6, meaning 6 items and 266 instances of quantity 7 and so on for all the orders where the unit price was greater than 1000. Hence, the higher the quantity lower the count.

The result we get from a subquery is passed to the main query in order to generate complex and more refined results. Moreover, Alias is used to give a temporary name to column or tables. Let’s see the example of using both of them to generate the result.
The subquery here returns the minimum unit price for each particular ID. So, if SalesOrderDetailID of 1 had 5 items, it will return the minimum price out of all those 5 items, and similarly for ID 2.

Then the main query will return order quantity and line total where the unit price matches with the unit price outputted by subquery. The s1 and s2 are called alias and are a great help for joining tables.

It means, we had one instance where quantity was 1 and line total was 2024.99400 for the minimum unit price belonging to an ID. Then there is another instance of quantity 1 with certain line total based on minimum price.
The IN clause can be used with sub queries as follows:

In this statement, we only get the names those people from person table for which the BusinessEntityID also exists in the subquery, and the subquery returns the BusinessEntityID from Sales table for business having sales higher than 2000000.
The EXISTS clause can be used with sub query as follows:

The subquery only returns Boolean values rather than certain values that can be matched with other columns. Therefore, whenever online order is flagged 1, it return a TRUE and if not than FALSE. In other words, the outer query only works based on TRUE and FALSE condition provided by subquery.
It simply checks for rows that have Order quantity between 4 and 6.

It is simply an if-then-else statement. It checks for a condition, and if it is true, then it returns a certain value if not, it moves to else part. We can define many if-then statements and one else statement. It can be used anywhere in the whole script as long as if follows the rules of SQL

The code above simply says that select the OrderQty column and if it is 1 then print “order quantity is 1” and similarly do it for others too until you hit else where rest of the values will be printed as “Greater than 3”
Window Functions are useful for comparison of sales, profit and other metrics.
This is a snapshot of the real table that we will apply window function on.
Here is the snapshot of the result.

A stored procedure is useful when we have to write a piece of code again and again. Rather, we can create a stored procedure, define an argument and then execute the procedure using EXECUTE command. The variable we define is written after @ and then used in WHERE clause.
The result gives us all the values where standard cost is greater than the value passed to cost_limit variable during execution (in this case 10).

First, we declare variables, then, we start the IF statement and check if the count of transaction type is greater than 1. If the condition is true the BEGIN section will be executed. SET keyword is used to store values of select statement into the variables. Once the variables are set I have used the print statement to print the vales of variables suing the concatenation functionality of SQL. Note that CAST function can be useful in converting the datatype of variables.
An additional query that uses both stored procedure as well as IF-ELSE function to output result.
